awd_titl_txt: Preparing Cities for Climate Change: An International Comparative Assessment of Urban Adaptation Planning
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this project is to conduct an international comparative assessment of urban adaptation planning.  Cities throughout the world are experiencing chronic problems and extreme events that are being attributed climate change. Although there is a critical need for cities to protect their built, natural, and human environments, there is notable variability in the approaches they are taking. At one extreme, some cities are developing dedicated and integrated climate adaptation plans. At the other extreme are cities that have not established any plans or initiated any adaptation measures whatsoever. Drawing on theories of diffusion and capacity, and case study and survey methodologies, this comparative international research examines: (1) the types of plans for climate adaptation being adopted in cities; (2) factors associated with differences in the approaches urban municipalities are taking toward climate adaptation planning; and (3) the ways that the efforts of nongovernmental and community-based organizations complement, circumvent, and replace government adaptation initiatives.
 
The results from this inquiry will expand our understanding of the forces and factors shaping decisions related to urban climate action. They also will deepen our knowledge of how civil society actors affect the capacity local governments. Disaster risk reduction is a critical component of climate adaptation planning. Therefore, as a consequence of studying adaptation, this research will enhance our understanding of the social and political dimensions of planning for natural disasters. To ensure that the policy-relevant results reach decision-makers in cities, the findings will be summarized in a report and disseminated to members of climate and local government networks. The research findings also will form the basis for case studies that can be used in graduate-level courses and will contribute to the development of a web tool designed to assist cities in their adaptation initiatives. In addition to generating policy and educational materials, graduate students will have opportunities to gain experience conducting research in international settings.

Overview

Cities around the world are facing greater variability in temperature, precipitation, and natural hazards that they are attributing to global climate change. These types of changes can place stress on urban infrastructure, decrease the habitability of many buildings, tax services, and, in the process, create housing, health and livelihood hardships for the most vulnerable residents. Minimizing the impacts of climate change requires that cities make concerted efforts to protect natural systems, the built environment, and human populations.

Since urban climate adaptation is a nascent policy domain, there is a great deal to be learned about planning and implementation, both in domestic and international contexts. Therefore, this research combined comparative case study, focus group, and survey methodologies, to: (1) Understand the ways in which exogenous pressures versus endogenous goals and priorities are affecting urban planning decisions and actions;  (2) Identify how variations in levels of economic development affect the ways cities are planning for climate impacts; (3) Investigate the roles diverse stakeholders play in shaping the capacity, actions, and decisions of local governments; and (4) Assess the relationship between urban climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction initiatives.

Intellectual Merit

This research contributes to our knowledge of urban climate adaptation while deepening our understanding of how cities take action in new policy domains. The findings demonstrate that cities characterized as early adapters, and that are motivated by endogenous factors, often initiate adaptation planning in order to reduce risks, achieve goals, and enhance city reputation. The findings also show that cities taking action in non-institutionalized policy domains develop a foundation for initiatives by building support within local government departments and, since they are dealing with scientific uncertainty and limited resources, by selecting measures that are flexible and can be implemented incrementally. Further, this research suggests that early adapters tend to innovate, testing ideas, learning from their efforts, and adjusting their course of action as needed.

Broader Implications

The results of this research demonstrate the types of challenges cities are encountering and offer insight into measures that will enable them to advance adaptation programs. The findings have been disseminated to the scholarly community through journal articles, book chapters, and conference presentations and to the policy community through reports and presentations at seminars, workshops, and meetings hosted by local governments and intergovernmental and international organizations. The students who assisted with this research received training in field interviewing, focus group facilitation, survey development and implementation, and qualitative and quantitative data analysis techniques. They also gave academic and policy presentations and collaborated on writing academic journal articles and policy reports.

Summary of Outcomes

Overall, 48% of the cities that participated in the survey have experienced variations in temperature and precipitation they attribute to climate change, while 68% indicate that they are taking steps to adapt. The U.S. had the lowest percentage of cities pursuing adaptation (59%) and Latin America the highest (95%). Only about half of cities that have accepted a plan or are engaged in implementation have conducted a formal risk or vulnerability assessment.
